Dear MEREDITH SMILLIE:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on December 19, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (h) Documentation from the department
that the person has not been named in a
central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5
years preceding hire.
One of four new employee files did not have a Central Registry clearance
completed as required.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household
must have training in and maintain a current
certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation from the American Heart
Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.

One of six foster home files reviewed did not have verification of current
CPR/First Aid as required.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Four of six foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (6) An agency shall do all the following:
• (a) Provide the foster parent with a copy
of the report required by subrule (5) of
this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not have documentation the
foster parent was provided a copy of the report within 10 days as required.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Four of six foster care files reviewed had an Updated Service Plan submitted
outside of the required timeframe.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Update checklists/monitoring tools to address missing items identified during
audit.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2024SEC0001915 was initiated on 9/18/2024 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline.

The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A CAP was implemented and has been completed.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 1/26/24 and the CAP was approved
on 3/5/2024. The agency was cited for 10 violations, 1 of which were repeated this
year. Of those 1, there was an increase in individual incidents of non-compliance.
In 2023, 18 violations were established, 2 of which were repeated this year. All of
the repeated violations remain close to the name number of individual incidents of
non-compliances. The agency will need to establish additional corrective planning
for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The Chief Administrator
indicated the agency faced some barriers that impacted overall compliance. They
were without a parenting time/case aide through most of the year which meant
case workers were providing a lot of transportation for children and families as well
as supervising the parenting time. This took away time from direct casework. In
addition, the agency terminated a caseworker who struggled managing the
workload and, as a result, significantly impacted overall compliance. The agency
continues to utilize internal and external supports to monitor cases and ensure
compliance. The assessment noted staff have kept the CAP and compliance at
the forefront and have worked diligently to serve youth and families. The chief
administrator reported confidence the agency will continue to see improvement
over the next review period.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the agency’s
financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff were interviewed via telephone. Staff reported feeling supported by
coworkers and supervisors. There were no concerns reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
